sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: A Turing program consists of a list of statements and declarations.
sections.text_content: A Turing program consists of a list of statements and declarations.
sections.mdown_content: A Turing program consists of a list of statements and declarations.

sections.title: Example
sections.raw_content: This is a complete Turing program. It outputs Alan M. Turing.
sections.text_content: This is a complete Turing program. It outputs Alan M. Turing.
sections.mdown_content: This is a complete Turing program. It outputs *Alan M. Turing*.

sections.title: Example
code:
var stars : string := "*"
        loop
            put stars
            stars := stars + "*"
        end loop
sections.raw_content: This is a complete Turing program. It outputs a triangle of stars.
sections.text_content: This is a complete Turing program. It outputs a triangle of stars.
sections.mdown_content: This is a complete Turing program. It outputs a triangle of stars.

sections.title: Example
code:
procedure sayItAgain ( what : string, n : int )
            for i : 1 .. n
                put what
            end for
        end sayItAgain
        
        sayItAgain ( "Hello", 1)
        sayItAgain ( "Goodbye", 2 )
sections.raw_content: This is a complete Turing program. It outputs Hello once and Goodbye twice.
sections.text_content: This is a complete Turing program. It outputs Hello once and Goodbye twice.
sections.mdown_content: This is a complete Turing program. It outputs *Hello *once and *Goodbye* twice.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: In a program there can be many units (see unit), one of which is the program (called the main program), the others of which are modules, monitors and classes. The main program is optionally preceded by an import list, which lists the units that it uses.
sections.text_content: In a program there can be many units (see unit), one of which is the program (called the main program), the others of which are modules, monitors and classes. The main program is optionally preceded by an import list, which lists the units that it uses.
sections.mdown_content: In a program there can be many units (see **unit**), one of which is the program (called the main program), the others of which are modules, monitors and classes. The main program is optionally preceded by an **import** list, which lists the units that it uses.
